data.title: Block Eliminates Bloat To Deliver Ambitious 2028 Target - Wait For Correction
data.description:
I previously covered Block (XYZ) in January 2026, discussing why I had reiterated my Buy rating then, thanks to the promising insights offered by the twice raised FY2025 guidance and the outsized 2028 targets offered during the 2025 Investor Day - as the management projected double-digit growth rates through numerous AI-driven initiatives.

This was significantly aided by the cheap valuations against historical averages/peers, the excellent capital appreciation prospects, and the value creation from the ongoing share repurchases.

In this article, I shall discuss why I am reiterating my Buy rating for the XYZ stock here, with the management notably delivering against their ambitious 2028 growth target as observed in the FQ4 '25 outperformance, the raised FY2026 guidance, and the bottom-line tailwinds from the drastic headcount reduction.

This is significantly aided by their improving business metrics, the stock's still compelling valuations, and the robust use of their growing free cash flow for share repurchases.

XYZ's Commitment To 2028 Growth Targets

Since then, XYZ has been impacted during the ongoing market rotation, with the stock losing -31.3% of its value between the January 2026 highs to the February 2026 lows.

Well, this is before XYZ's outsized one-day gains of +16.8% post-FQ4 '25 earnings call, as the market rejoices at three key developments:

1. Drastic Headcount Reduction

Much of XYZ's tailwinds may be attributed to the management's drastic reduction in their headcounts by -40% along with the raised FY2026 gross profit/operating income guidance, with it signaling their confidence in delivering the accelerated, profitable growth trends through a notably leaner operation.

The headcount reduction builds upon the ongoing reduction to:

  • 10,205 employees in FY2025 (-10.2% YoY),
  • 11,372 employees in FY2024 (-12.4% YoY),

after the multi-year headcount expansion at

  • 12,985 employees in FY2023 (+4.4% YoY),
  • 12,428 employees in FY2022 (+45.8% YoY),
  • 8,521 employees in FY2021 (+55.5% YoY),
  • 5,477 employees in FY2020 (+42.8% YoY), and
  • 3,835 employees in FY2019 (+14.5% YoY).

Based on the ongoing headcount expansion at a 6Y CAGR of +17.7% against their revenue growth at +31.3% over the same time period, it may appear that XYZ's planned headcount reduction may have been overly done indeed, given the growing headcounts' notable contribution to their top-line growth thus far.

This is especially true when comparing XYZ's revenue per employee metric at $2.37M in FY2025 (+11.7% YoY) against its direct fintech peers, including:

  • Neo bank/investment - SoFi Technologies, Inc. (SOFI) at $591K in FY2025 (FY2025 revenues of $3.61B and 6,100 employees),
  • AI lending platform - Upstart (UPST) at $740K in FY2025 (based on FY2025 revenues of $1.04B and 1,405 employees),
  • Neo bank - LendingClub Corporation (LC) at $929K (FY2025 revenues of $998.84M and 1,075 employees),
  • PSP/P2P/BNPL - PayPal Holdings, Inc. (PYPL) at $1.39M (FY2025 revenues of $33.17B and 23,800 employees), and
  • BNPL - Affirm Holdings, Inc. (AFRM) at $1.45M in FY2025 (FY2025 revenues of $3.22B and 2,206 employees),

with it apparent that XYZ's operations remain rather efficient thus far, albeit still a distance away from the supposed market leader in the financial market, StoneX at $23.76M of revenue per employee in early 2025, as reported by Ondeck in November 2025.

On the other hand, given the drastic headcount reduction of -40%, it goes without saying that XYZ is likely to report a notably higher metric at an estimated FY2026 sum of $4.45M per employee (+87.7% YoY), based on the consensus FY2026 revenue estimates of $26.75B (+10.5% YoY) and ~6,000 employees after reduction.

Given that the revenue per employee metric "is an important ratio that roughly measures how much money each employee generates for the company," it goes without saying that the management appears determined to deliver their ambitious 2028 growth targets.

If anything, a similar cadence has been observed in Verizon (VZ), as the new CEO also touts how “cost reductions will be a way of life for us here” and the strategy is expected to fund their “significant investment” towards reclaiming their market leadership in the telecom segment.

These developments are unsurprising indeed, as observed in the market-wide layoffs post-COVID-19 pandemic, significantly aided by the productivity gains during the ongoing AI boom.

2. Raised FY2026 Guidance

It is also important to note that XYZ has already raised their FY2026 guidance, with the gross profit guidance of $12.2B (+18% YoY) and the adj. operating income guidance of $3.2B (+53.8% YoY), notably building upon the FY2025 levels of $10.36B (+17% YoY) and $2.08B (+29.1% YoY), respectively.

Assuming that the fintech is able to sustain these growth rates, it is not overly aggressive to assume that they may also eventually achieve their 2028 growth targets previously offered in the 2025 Investors Day, with the projected:

  • gross profit growth to $15.8B in FY2028, expanding at a 3Y CAGR of +15.1%, and
  • adj operating income growth to $4.6B in FY2028, expanding at a 3Y CAGR of +30.2%,

significantly aided by the likely to be reduced operating expenses from the drastic headcount reduction.

Readers must also note the accretive impact from XYZ's ongoing share repurchases on its adj. EPS growth to $0.65 in FQ4 '25 (+38.2% YoY), thanks to -3.5% of its float already retired over the LTM and the richer adj. net income margins of 6.4% in FQ4 '25 (+1.4 points YoY).

These reasons are also why I am of the opinion that XYZ still looks compelling at my estimated FY2026 P/E non-GAAP valuations of 17.46x, based on the current stock prices of $63.94 and the fintech's FY2026 adj EPS guidance of $3.66 (+54.4% YoY).

This is especially since the management still expects to deliver adjusted EPS of $5.50 in FY2028, expanding at a 3Y CAGR of +32.3%, with the stock still cheap at my estimated 3Y PEG non-GAAP ratio of 0.54x against the 5Y mean of 2.28x.

When comparing against the sector median of 1.01x and its direct fintech peers, including:

  • UPST at 3Y PEG non-GAAP ratio of 0.42x (using the same methodology),
  • AFRM at 0.44x,
  • SOFI at 0.81x,
  • LC at 0.21x, and
  • PYPL at 1.27x,

it is apparent that XYZ has remained compellingly valued as a fintech stock for so long that the management is able to leverage their "intelligence tools" and "significantly smaller team" to successfully execute their 2028 growth target.

This is especially since XYZ still reports a relatively decent balance sheet health at a net debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 0.06x in FY2025, compared to some of its peers, including AFRM at 1.50x, SOFI at -2.96x (more cash than debt), and PYPL at 0.06x.

These underscore XYZ's ability to incrementally invest in their growth initiatives while directing much of their free cash flow generation of $2.42B (+17.4% YoY) towards future share retirement, with $5.3B still remaining in authorization.

3. Return To Growth

Much of XYZ's ability to deliver the aggressive 2028 targets is linked to their determination to return to growth, through:

  • the expanded merchant network to drive higher user acquisition trends,
  • the expanded lending and banking products to drive higher user engagement and cross-selling trends,

all of which are expected to drive improved monetization trends and higher Gross Payment Volumes [GPV] across both Cash App and Square.

The same has been observed in Cash App's Monthly Transacting Active growth to 59M in FQ4 '25 (+2M YoY) and Primary Banking Actives to 9.3M (+1.7M YoY), along with the growing Inflows Per Transacting Active at $1.41K (+11.9% YoY), as "more customers bring their paychecks into Cash App."

The latter is important indeed, since "these customers have generated nearly 10x the gross profit of peer-to-peer only actives," with it also triggering higher retention trends and spending volumes through the Cash App Card.

Thanks to the tailwinds from the prior Fed rate cuts in late 2025, the fintech has also reported growing "consumer lending origination volume by 50% year-over-year in 2025, while sustaining strong margins and healthy risk loss performance," as similarly reported by other lenders/BNPL players in the recent Q4 '25 earnings season.

This is on top of XYZ Square's growing GPV by +10% YoY, as their international expansion drives accelerated GPV growth by +25% YoY compared to the US at +7% YoY, aided by their expansion into the mid-market seller channels (>$500K in annualized GPV).

Most importantly, despite the growth initiatives and the intensified R&D efforts, the fintech has been able to report a notable expansion in their adjusted operating margins to 20% in FQ4 '25 (+3 points YoY) and to 20% in FY2025 as well (+2 points YoY), with it lending credence to their increasingly efficient operations.

The excellent Return On Investment [ROI] on their growth initiatives may also be why the market has rewarded the XYZ stock with the outsized double-digit rally post-FQ4 '25 earnings call, with the fintech seemingly on track to reverse their previously decelerating growth profile in FY2024/FY2025 while delivering the ambitious 2028 growth targets.

XYZ Remains A Great Buy Upon A Correction

For now, the bulls continue to prove XYZ's new trading floor at the $50s as the euphoric one-day rally pushes the stock to the $63s, thanks to the FQ4 '25 outperformance, the raised FY2026 guidance, and the bottom-line tailwinds from the drastic headcount reduction.

Despite this, I am of the opinion that stock is still a great buy, since there remains an excellent upside potential of +50.1% to my long-term price target of $96, based on the FY2026 P/E non-GAAP valuations of 17.46x and the management's FY2028 adj EPS of $5.50.

If anything, readers must note that XYZ remains cheap against the peer group 1Y P/E mean of ~25x, with the speculative upgrading in the former's valuations nearer to its peers likely to trigger an extremely rich, more than doubling upside potential to my bull-case long-term price target of $137.50.

This conjecture is not overly aggressive as well, since the fintech sector as a whole has been oversold upon the potential emergence of a "K-shaped economy" from the divergence between the "higher-income consumers, who are benefiting from stock-market and home-price gains, continue to spend" and the "lower-income individuals are cutting back as inflation eats into their spending power and the job market tightens."

This is worsened by the recent tariff uncertainties, with further trade disruptions and prolonged macroeconomic normalization being more likely than not - with it already contributing to the fintech sector's steep selloff as observed in the Global X FinTech ETF's (FINX) correction by -31.3% from the 52 week highs.

While it may take some time for the macroeconomic environment and market sentiments to recover, I am of the opinion that XYZ presents a compelling capital appreciation opportunity for those looking to tap into their promising fintech revival through 2028.

Thanks to the outsized one-day stock price action, it is unsurprising that XYZ has seemingly entered overbought territories by the time of writing, as observed in the elevated RSIs and the 20% gap to its established uptrend support line since October 2023.

As a result, I urge readers to wait for part of the exuberance to be moderated before adding, preferably nearer to the Q4 '25 support levels of $57s for an improved margin of safety.

Given the potential -10% downside from current levels, some patience may be quite prudent indeed.

data.title: Amazon: Not The Best Bang For Your Buck
data.description:
In late November, I upgraded Amazon.com, Inc. (AMZN) to a hold rating as AWS growth reaccelerated and the valuation was deemed fair. However, due to soft guidance and stiff competition in the cloud services space, I decided to remain cautious. As you can see in the chart below, my hesitation to call Amazon a buy has paid off, as the stock has slid significantly after the company's most recent earnings. Today, we'll take a look at these results as well as talk about important developments and the valuation.

Below, it is shown that Q4 was a mixed quarter for Amazon. While AWS growth continued to rebound, it still lagged growth seen in key competitors. Furthermore, North America sales weakness is concerning moving forward. While profitability looked quite strong for Q4, guidance for 2026 Q1 was soft in my view. Furthermore, with the valuation not particularly low, I would say that there is limited opportunity for investors. As a result, I have decided to stick with my hold rating for now.

Sales Analysis

For 2025 Q4, Amazon reported top-line results that were slightly mixed on some aspects. The company generated total sales worth $213.4 billion, and while the growth rate of 14% isn't bad relative to what we have seen in the past few years, the acceleration from the previous quarter was quite minimal. Furthermore, in constant currency terms, the sales growth rate was actually unchanged at 12%, and so momentum doesn't seem to be building at this point. Still, Amazon actually beat expectations by $2.15 billion.

The other point of concern is the weakness and underperformance in their North America segment. As you can see on the right, the North America eCommerce segment is still by far their largest by net sales. In Q4, growth decelerated to 10% from the previous quarter's already quite sluggish 11% increase. Meanwhile, International sales growth accelerated both in reported and constant currency terms. This is clearly a demonstration of the erosion of consumer confidence that has happened in the United States as a result of tariffs and still quite sticky inflation.

That said, the company's strategic decision to continue pushing into pharmacy services is one that could help to drive growth in their North America segment moving forward. On Feb 11th, it was reported that Amazon is targeting same-day delivery to 4,500 U.S. cities by the end of CY2026. This boosts Amazon's competitiveness in this space. Next, let's turn to a closer look at their all-important AWS segment.

AWS Growth Continues To Rebound

The focus is, without a doubt, on AWS in this age of AI. There were some promising results in this key segment. For Q4, they reported net sales of $35.579 billion, and that represented growth of 24% YoY. This is a speedup of growth compared to Q3's 20% growth rate, and so there are signs that momentum is starting to pick up. It is not surprising that the cloud market share leader is growing slower than its largest competitors, but the gap in growth versus Alphabet (GOOG) (GOOGL) and Microsoft (MSFT) may be a little bit unnerving.

In their most recent earnings report, Google Cloud saw a 48% increase in revenues, while Microsoft Azure saw 39% growth. Of course, AWS has a larger growth base, but if Amazon continues to lag other hyperscalers over the long run, there is a risk that it will lose its crown in cloud services. That said, they do seem to be making some meaningful moves that will help to drive better performance over time.

We'll talk about their CapEx a little later, but just a few days ago, Amazon announced that they will invest $12 billion to build data centers in Louisiana. As Ahmed Farhath of Seeking Alpha writes, "Louisiana has become a hotbed for AI infrastructure projects due to significant tax benefits, low electricity rates, and a reliable power grid." Therefore, it seems that Amazon is making a good strategic decision and investment to boost the presence of AWS. While spending may scare off some investors, at this point, it really does seem that Amazon has to invest heavily in data centers to secure the long run success of AWS.

Just today (Feb 27th), it was confirmed by OpenAI that Amazon would be investing $50 billion into the company. In addition to the investment, it was also announced that OpenAI would deepen its commitment to using AWS. Moving forward, AWS will be "the exclusive third-party cloud distribution provider for OpenAI Frontier, which enables organizations to build, deploy, and manage teams of AI agents." Furthermore, OpenAI will be consuming 2 GW of Trainium capacity. This is a big deal for AWS and for their Trainium chips in particular, as it is a vote of confidence that there is strong demand for Amazon's in-house chips. Moving forward, securing more deals like these will help AWS solidify its lead in cloud services.

As a whole, I would say that AWS is moving in the right direction. While growth still trails Google Cloud and Azure, they are seeing a good amount of re-acceleration in this key segment. Furthermore, as highlighted above, new data center investments and a deepening relationship with OpenAI are likely to drive AWS' performance in the long run.

Profitability Better Than It Seems

While the EPS growth rate was quite poor, as shown above, profitability is better than it seems. For the bottom line, Amazon reported an EPS of $1.95, just meeting expectations and representing a sluggish growth rate of 5% YoY. However, a steep increase in provision for income taxes was a major factor in these numbers. When looking at the true profitability of Amazon's operations, things weren't bad at all.

For operating income, they saw an 18% increase. This outpaces the top-line growth rate as a sign of good business efficiency. Furthermore, when excluding the three special charges listed in their earnings release, operating margin would have been even better. As a result, I believe profitability is not a major concern at this point.

CapEx Soars

Above, the TTM numbers are shown for Amazon's cash flows and CapEx. As you can see, while operating cash flows have grown quite healthily, the company's capital spending has exploded. FCFs are clearly on a downtrend, and with the company announcing that CapEx will be around $200 billion for 2026, investors may have their doubts.

In my view, management is probably doing what's right for the company. AWS growth is lagging Azure and Google Cloud, and for them to maintain their CSP crown, they are going to have to spend. Investments in data centers and infrastructure are likely to drive shareholder value over time, but in the meantime, investors are going to have to sit with deteriorating FCFs and perhaps even negative FCFs at some point down the road.

Outlook Is Soft

For 2026 Q1, Amazon sees net sales growth in the range of 11% to 15%. At the midpoint, they're implying a modest growth slowdown from Q4's 14%. I wasn't overly impressed by the slight acceleration of growth in Q4 from Q3 levels, and so I would have to say that top line guidance for Q1 is a bit soft. Still, this was actually above consensus expectations.

For operating income, they are expecting to see around $19 billion at the midpoint of their guidance range. This implies a growth rate of just 3% YoY. While the company did state that their estimate for operating income includes higher Amazon Leo costs for the scaling of that business, overall profitability may still be a bit shaky moving forward. As a whole, I'm unimpressed with Amazon's near-term outlook even if their strategic decisions and investments are beneficial for the long term.

Valuation Not That Attractive

While Amazon's forward P/E ratio has dipped so far in 2026, it is still above Microsoft's and Alphabet's. I believe this shows that Amazon stock is relatively unattractive right now.

For some context, Microsoft and Alphabet posted company-wide growth rates of 17% and 18%, respectively, in their most recent quarter. This outpaces the growth rate for Amazon. Furthermore, recall that AWS growth lags both Azure and Google Cloud by a large margin. Therefore, while there are obviously business model differences between the companies, Amazon seems to be rather expensive relative to where their fundamentals stand in the grand scheme of things.

Furthermore, while strategic moves are justified, the near-term outlook is undesirable as per their guidance. In a recent article, I called Microsoft a strong buy, but Amazon likely only remains a hold at this point.

Conclusion

Amazon stock plunged post-earnings, and it's not that hard to see why. Their largest segment by sales, North America, is underperforming, and despite better AWS momentum, Azure and Google Cloud continue to take the spotlight. While developments like their pharmacy push and their OpenAI deal are positive, guidance shows that the outlook is unfavorable at least for the near term. As stated above, company-wide growth and cloud growth at Amazon trail both Microsoft and Alphabet, yet the valuation is higher. I believe this shows the risk/reward is not where investors want it to be, and so I have decided to maintain my hold rating on Amazon.

data.title: Emergent BioSolutions Earnings: Revenue, Margins, And GAAP Losses Paint A Mixed Picture
data.description:
Thesis

Emergent BioSolutions Inc. (EBS) closed about 27% lower on Friday. I think it’s safe to say that the slide was driven less by the 2025 results but more by a major negative reset in 2026 expectations. Management guided to just $720 to $760 million in 2026 revenue, a range that was far below the roughly $1.0 billion level that analysts had been modelling. Elsewhere, management guided for adjusted EBITDA of $135 to $155 million, down from $205 million in 2025, alongside an expected return to a GAAP net loss. So overall, it didn’t make for great viewing, and the size of the expectations gap, not just the weaker fundamentals, which I’ll get to, is what really hurt the stock price. Now, I think the sheer size of the guidance told us that 2025 profitability was boosted by a pretty favourable mix and cost dynamics that will not repeat any time soon. The competitive pressure on naloxone, combined with the uneven government procurement, should weigh rather heavily on 2026. So overall, with lower revenue on the horizon and a sharp dip in profitability expected, I wouldn't be too bullish on Emergent shares, which now find themselves trading in the $8 range.

Financial results

Emergent showed us a much-improved FY25 financial performance in 2025. We’re starting to see the impact of their multi-year turnaround strategy. Now, despite a steep 29% year-over-year decline in total revenue to $742.9 million, the company actually swung from a net loss of $190.6 million in 2024 to a net income of $52.6 million in 2025. This was, of course, mainly driven by some very aggressive cost controls. We also saw improved manufacturing efficiency and a far richer product mix. Gross margin managed to expand to 45%, up from 26%, while adjusted gross margin rose to 54%. It’s a nice reflection of lower production costs and the reduced restructuring and shutdown expenses. Elsewhere, adjusted EBITDA hit $205.0 million, up about 12% year over year, so it’s clear that profitability gains were not just accounting-driven but also operational. As for cash flow from operations, the company has $170.6 million and a decent reduction in leverage, of which a big chunk came from a voluntary $100 million debt repayment and share repurchases totalling $24.8 million.

As for 4Q25, here’s where we see the real volatility that comes with Emergent’s revenue model. 4Q25 revenue fell about 24% to just $148.7 million, with the company reporting a net loss of $54.6 million. Now, this was mainly due to weaker naloxone sales and the overall timing of U.S. government and international medical countermeasure orders. In terms of naloxone, revenue has dropped 41% since generic competition has been piling on the pricing pressure. Also, smallpox MCM sales declined about 54% due to procurement timing. However, it’s worth mentioning that these declines were partially offset by a hefty 64% jump in anthrax MCM revenue. This goes to show just how important government-driven contract cycles are in quarterly performance.

Other segment results also show us a lot of divergence, with Commercial Products margins collapsing to 6% in 4Q25, again a result of the pricing pressure. Elsewhere, MCM Products' margins expanded to 44% with the help of some higher-margin products and favourable manufacturing variances. You can see the revenue compressions compared to last year in the chart below. As for guidance, we can expect much lower profitability in 2026, which is another thing investors wouldn’t have been too happy about on the call. Management guided for lower adjusted EBITDA in the range of $135 to $155 million and a return to a GAAP net loss. So that would suggest the 2025 strength benefited from the unusually favourable cost and mix dynamics.

Competition on naloxone

One of the big points on the call and also a trend we’ve been seeing in 2025 was the pressure on naloxone. There’s been massive competition and also some unpredictable government buying patterns, which haven’t helped. If we take these together, they would account for a lot of the conservatism in the 2026 guidance. On the competitive side of things, the U.S. naloxone market has shifted quite rapidly since the OTC conversion. There are now multiple low-cost generic and even store-brand versions entering retail channels. Management actually warned that anticipated price adjustments will more than likely offset volume growth in 2026, which is never a good sign. It tells me that whilst unit demand remains rather strong, revenue per dose is falling simply because states, municipalities, and NGOs are prioritising cheaper alternatives. This is mainly why we’re seeing commercial revenue get guided to only flat to slightly up despite broader overdose-response funding trends.

At the same time, what also didn’t help is that government procurement is still highly uneven. You can see in the 2025 results. They benefited from an exceptional $60 million international customer order, but management doesn’t expect it to repeat in 2026. So this made somewhat of a built-in year-over-year headwind. In addition to this, the U.S. government shutdown caused some disruptions in 4Q24. We saw temporary reductions in NARCAN demand since public agencies delayed purchasing decisions. What this showed us is that naloxone volumes can be driven more by budget timing and even administrative processes rather than by end-user need, which we would rather see. We should also stay realistic and understand that naloxone demand is not actually collapsing, but it's the revenue contribution that’s becoming less predictable and lower-margin. Emergent to guide very conservatively on both top line and profitability.

One-time $60 million international MCM order

I think it’s worth touching on the loss of a one-time $60 million international MCM order, since it boosted 2025 results a lot. It also seems it won’t recur anytime soon. That order made up about 8% of FY25 total revenue, and materially helped out with margins and EBITDA. The FY26 revenue is now expected to fall between $720 and $760 million, and even the top end of the range implies that the underlying business is only flat to slightly down. Which I feel is due to stripping out this non-repeat contribution. You see, a large portion of 2025’s growth was actually opportunistic rather than structural, and the absence alone explains most of that year-over-year revenue decline embedded in guidance. It’s also set to contribute to the projected drop in adjusted EBITDA from $205 million in FY25 to $135 to $155 million in 2026.

Valuation

Emergent, after this latest stock sell-off, now seems extremely discounted on a revenue-based valuation, especially given the company’s scale. They hold a market cap of about $583 million against a 2025 revenue figure of $742.9 million. The stock now trades at just 0.76x trailing sales and about 0.72x forward sales, which is a pretty steep discount to the healthcare sector median, nearing 3.7x. I find this particularly notable since they have specialised government-backed biodefense contracts and a gross margin profile that expanded to 45% in 2025. On an enterprise value basis, they trade at about 1.2x EV to sales and 4.3x EV to EBITDA, versus sector norms closer to 3.7x and 14x, respectively. So that would imply the market is assigning a hefty discount to Emergent’s durability of earnings and future revenue visibility, rather than its current operating performance.

So the way I see this is, despite appearing as optically cheap, the post-earnings valuation of Emergent now reflects a business that just reset its earnings power meaningfully lower. Not what investors would have wanted, but with that sharp reduction in 2026 revenue/EBITDA guidance, it has reframed 2025 as a peak year driven. The peak was driven by those one-off orders and unusually favourable cost dynamics rather than a sustainable run rate, which we would have preferred. So, to me, that means the market is no longer valuing Emergent on last year’s profitability but now on a structurally weaker forward profile. It also means naloxone pricing pressure, and that somewhat lumpy government procurement makes cash flows less predictable. If you look at it this way, the discount in the share price seems to be more like compensation for elevated uncertainty, especially around the durability of margins and future revenue visibility.

Looking ahead

FY25 now looks more like a profitability high-water mark rather than a new baseline. Adjusted EBITDA hit $205 million last year, and what helped was that aggressive $140 million reduction in operating expenses. We also saw a 900 basis-point expansion in gross margin, but despite all this, management’s FY26 outlook of $135 to $155 million in EBITDA implies that most of those easily achievable cost savings have already been realised. So we can expect margins to be constrained by lower revenue/pricing pressure, particularly in naloxone.

The other area I didn’t like seeing was the guidance for a return to GAAP net losses of $10 to $30 million this year. So non-cash charges, restructuring items, and legacy costs are still meaningful, and accounting profitability is still pretty fragile despite the turnaround narrative management has been giving us. Management also highlighted a capital allocation shift toward shareholders and some indication of balance sheet repair. We have to give them credit here since they did just announce the repurchase of 3.1 million shares and the authorisation of a new $50 million buyback program. They also had that $100 million voluntary term loan prepayment, which has left us with a year-end liquidity of $305 million. While these actions signal financial discipline and near-term confidence, they also raise more questions about prioritising financial engineering over reinvestment. And that’s at a time when EBITDA is projected to fall by roughly 25% to 35% year over year. If I take all this together—the peaking profitability, a return to GAAP losses, and a pivot toward buybacks rather than growth—I think the current setup gives me a cautious stance, leaving Emergent as a hold for me following this earnings report.

data.title: Morgan Stanley Direct Lending: 10% Dividend Reset
data.description:
Fears over defaulting loans in the SaaS space, a sector that private credit platforms heavily lend money to, have created serious selling pressure for BDCs lately, many of which are now trading at 52-week lows. While I recently came out with a number of articles heavily recommending some BDCs like Blackstone Secured Lending (BXSL) or Hercules Capital (HTGC), I don't see the same opportunity for Morgan Stanley Direct Lending Fund (MSDL): the investment firm did not fully support its dividend with net investment income in the last quarter, and management announced a reduction in the regular dividend to $0.45 per-share (a 10% reduction). Further, falling base rates and a rise in non-accruals are concerns that prevent me from upgrading MSDL to buy at this point, despite shares being oversold and trading at fresh 52-week lows.

Previous rating

Morgan Stanley Direct Lending was a hold in my last coverage -- No Safety Margin -- due to its strong focus on first liens but its inability to generate excess dividend coverage. Morgan Stanley Direct Lending fell short of its dividend in the fourth quarter as well, highlighting growing concerns about the BDC's NII trajectory. While shares are trading well below net asset value and 'SaaSpocalypse' fears have gotten way out of hand, in my opinion, I do not recommend buying the drop here just yet.

SaaS-driven sell-off continues

Morgan Stanley Direct Lending is one of the leading BDCs in the market, with Morgan Stanley being the sponsor of this specific private credit platform. The BDC is externally managed by MS Capital Partners Adviser and chiefly originates variable rate-paying senior secured loans.

Morgan Stanley Direct Lending is a first lien-focused BDC which is the kind of BDC that I would generally prefer to invest in given a high degree of principal protection... if it weren't for the investment firm's recent coverage problems. In the most recent quarter, Morgan Stanley Direct Lending had a portfolio value of $3.77B, showing a 0.5% contraction year-over-year.

Higher investment losses and a rise in non-accruals raise concerns about dividend coverage in 2026, as well as the fact that the investment firm did not fully support its dividend with net investment income in Q4'25. About 96% of all investments are made in the first lien category.

Besides a falling portfolio value, due to high repayment activity and net realized investment losses in Q4'25 ($8.1M), Morgan Stanley Direct Lending now has a coverage and a non-accrual problem, which I expect to weigh on MSDL's valuation factor in the months ahead.

The investment firm had a non-accrual ratio, at cost, of 1.6% as of the end of the fourth quarter, showing a massive 700% increase year-over-year. Other BDCs that I have covered, like Ares Capital (ARCC) or Blackstone Secured Lending, had non-accrual ratios of 1.8% and 0.6%. While BXSL has also seen a deterioration of its portfolio quality due to a higher number of non-performing loans, the BDC still ranks at the top of the performance chart: Why I Am Buying The SaaS crash.

$M Q4'24 Q1'25 Q2'25 Q3'25 Q4'25 Y/Y Growth
Total Investments $3,792 $3,788 $3,786 $3,776 $3,772 -0.5%
Non-Accrual (at cost) 0.2% 0.2% 0.7% 1.2% 1.6% 700.0%

Source: Author

A new risk: NII downtrend leads to dividend cut

In the fourth quarter, Morgan Stanley Direct Lending generated total net investment income of $42.4M, showing a year-over-year drop-off rate of 16%. The decline in income is mainly due to a contraction in interest and dividend income (-8% Y/Y) which made up 94% of the investment firm's total investment income in the fourth quarter.

As was the case with other private credit platforms lately, Morgan Stanley Direct Lending saw a shrinking of its portfolio value amid lower interest income from loans, which also caused a double-digit decline in per-share net investment income.

As a result, the investment firm was no longer able to fully fund its dividend with current quarter earnings (NII). The dividend coverage in Q4'25 was 98%, which is the first NII underperformance in the last year. As a result, the BDC lowered its dividend by 10% to $0.45 per-share quarterly.

With the current quarter's NII no longer being sufficient to support the $0.50 per-share dividend, and a dividend cut announced, I believe Morgan Stanley Direct Lending will suffer from weak investor sentiment for a while... which may very well lead to a higher NAV discount in the short term.

Q3'24 Q4'24 Q1'25 Q2'25 Q3'25 Growth Y/Y
NII Per-Share $0.57 $0.52 $0.50 $0.50 $0.49 -14.0%
Total Dividend $0.50 $0.50 $0.50 $0.50 $0.50 0.0%
Coverage Ratio 114.0% 104.0% 100.0% 100.0% 98.0% -14.0%

Source: Author

10% dividend cut weighs on valuation, as do SaaS fears

Morgan Stanley Direct Lending is currently priced at a 27% discount to net asset value, which makes the BDC much cheaper than shares of Ares Capital and Blackstone Secured Lending, which have NAV discounts of 7% and 12%. Both BDCs are top-rated, however, and have delivered strong results for shareholders over time, especially Ares Capital... which is why the BDC is still priced at a relatively high P/NAV ratio. My current rating on ARCC is hold: A Robust 10% Yield For Trying Times.

While I believe that the SaaS sell-off is completely exaggerated, as I explained here, I would currently not recommend investors buy the drop in Morgan Stanley Direct Lending because of the negative sentiment overhang following the 10% dividend cut. In addition, the investment firm's 700% increase in non-accruals makes me uneasy, and the high net asset value discount now visible in the market reflects this.

In the longer term, assuming SaaS concerns prove to be unfounded and the sector recovers, I can see MSDL revaluing to its 3-year average P/NAV ratio of 0.95X. As of the end of the fourth quarter, MSDL's net asset value stood at $20.26 per share, so a fair value for the BDC may be around $19.28 per-share... which reconciles to the historical P/NAV ratio. This fair value may only be realized, however, if the BDC manages to transition to higher asset quality (implying a lower non-performing loan ratio, at least below 1.0%) and if its dividend coverage profile gets restored to at least 100% going forward.

Risks with Morgan Stanley Direct Lending

MSDL has ~20% exposure to the SaaS and software sectors in its portfolio -- about on-par with other BDCs -- which in the perception of investors, has become a major risk, given the discussion about AI disruption lately. I believe AI and SaaS fears are exaggerated, and investors are likely well-advised to refrain from panic selling until actual evidence mounts that this is in fact the case.

What would specifically change my opinion and my stock rating on Morgan Stanley Direct Lending is if the BDC were to see; 1) an increase in the non-accrual ratio above 2.0%, 2) a drop in the dividend coverage ratio below 100% for two or more consecutive quarters even after the dividend was cut, or 3) a significant increase in defaults in loans that the company has made to the SaaS/software industry.

Final thoughts

All things considered, I believe the value proposition for Morgan Stanley Direct Lending has not improved that much in the last several weeks, despite a higher net asset value discount. Morgan Stanley Direct Lending did not fully support its dividend with net investment income, and the investment firm actually has seen a material increase in its non-accrual percentage. In my opinion, the 27% discount to net asset value reflects concerns about the firm's NII trajectory, dividend coverage, and balance sheet quality. While I don't see the dividend cut as a specific reason to downgrade or sell MSDL, a dividend reset it always disappointing and can be expected to weigh on investor sentiment for a while.

data.title: GigaCloud Proves The Bears Wrong - Compelling Risk/Reward After A Dip (Upgrade)
data.description:
I previously covered GigaCloud Technology Inc. (GCT) in November 2025, discussing why the stock had been downgraded to a Hold after the outsized rally post FQ3'25 earnings call, despite the robust FQ3'25 performance metrics, the promising FQ4'25 guidance, and the potentially accretive New Classic Home Furnishing acquisition.

With the stock already trading well beyond its historical trends and an upgrade nearer to its peers unlikely, I had believed that the stock had pulled forward much of its intermediate-term upside potential, with the overbought technical indicators and short interest ratio triggering a reduced margin of safety.

In this article, I shall discuss why I am upgrading the GCT stock as a Buy upon a slight dip, as the vertically integrated marketplace company proves my bearish thesis wrong by delivering robust sales expansion in the EU at a time of softer demand in the US.

This is while reporting a notably healthier balance sheet and an excellent shareholder return, thanks to the robust free cash flow generation, with it underscoring their attractively valued, profitable growth investment thesis.

GCT Proves Its Resilient Marketplace Platform

Since my last Hold rating, GCT has mostly traded sideways after enjoying the prior market rotation in late November 2025 and losing much of those gains in February 2026, before the bulls drive the stock's rather extreme rally by +33% post FQ4'25 earnings call.

Much of the tailwinds may be attributed to their ability to shift "more resources and focus to Europe in light of softness in the U.S. market," with it directly driving their Germany revenues (before distribution to the EU) to $322.02M in FY2025 (+68% YoY).

With their Germany revenues now comprising 24.9% of their overall FY2025 revenues (+8.4 points YoY), it is unsurprising that their success in the EU has been able to well balance the softer demand in the US at revenues of $854.9M (-3% YoY) while driving the more than decent overall revenue growth to $1.28B (+10.3% YoY).

Most importantly, despite their large exposure to the US and the potential tariff headwinds for large furniture imported into the country, it is apparent that GCT has been able to mitigate this risk through the higher pricing and the elevated off-platform sales, with it triggering their robust overall gross profit margins of 23% in FQ4'25 (+1 point YoY/+6 from FY2022 levels of 17%).

Despite the lower ocean shipping spot rates arising from the "Liberation Day (impact) across the broader economy" and the near-term noise on its deteriorating Services gross margins to 10.1% in FY2025 (-8.1 points YoY), I am not overly concerned, indeed, since it has been well balanced by the richer Products gross margins of 29.8% (+2.1 points YoY).

This is on top of the higher adoption of their last-mile offerings, including packing and fulfillment services, with it signaling the success of GCT's vertically integrated end to end marketplace platform as they also onboard:

  • more active 3P sellers to 1,299 in FQ4'25 (+16.2% YoY) and
  • more active buyers to 12,089 (+29.9% YoY),

all of which are already driving their overall GigaCloud Marketplace GMV expansion to $1.57B in FY2025 (+17.5% YoY).

Combined with their improved operating discipline and the expanding scale, it is unsurprising that GCT has been able to report the richer adj EBITDA margins of 11.8% in FQ4'25 (+1.4 points YoY/+3.3 from FY2022 levels of 8.5%).

These lend credence to their highly resilient operations in the face of regulatory uncertainties, partly aided by the rationalized SKUs, the strategic/accretive M&A efforts, and the expanded marketplace/infrastructure operations to 7 facilities in the EU.

As a result of their ability to competently navigate a challenging macroeconomic environment to drive robust, profitable marketplace growth, I can understand why the market and the bulls have already awarded GCT with the outsized, one-day stock price rally of +33% post FQ4'25 earnings call.

GCT has also fed the exuberance through the outsized FQ1'26 revenue guidance of $342.5M at the midpoint (+25.9% YoY), with it perhaps contributing to the raised consensus forward estimates.

This is with the diversified marketplace player expected to report a robust top/bottom-line growth profile at a CAGR of +9.9%/+8.9% through FY2027 while building upon its historical growth profile at a 3Y CAGR of +38.1%/+81.5%, respectively.

As a result of their robust profitable growth prospects, it is unsurprising that GCT still looks compelling at FWD EV/Sales valuations of 1.12x and FWD EV/EBITDA valuations of 9.38x despite the upgrade from the 1Y mean of 0.92x/7.90x and the 3Y mean of 0.89x/6.99x, respectively, with the recent rally seemingly well balanced by the raised consensus forward estimates.

When comparing GCT's FWD EV/EBITDA valuations of 9.38x and the adj. EBITDA margins of 12.6% in FY2025 (-0.9 points YoY) to its diversified commerce peers, including:

  • Amazon (AMZN) at 11x/20.3% in FY2025 (diversified, including cloud and advertising),
  • MercadoLibre (MELI) at 17.90x/13.8% in FY2025 (diversified, including fintech),
  • Sea Limited (SE) at 16.07x/16.4% on a YTD basis (diversified, including neobank and gaming), and
  • Alibaba (BABA) at 16.31x/9.6% on a YTD basis (diversified, including cloud and entertainment), respectively...

...it appears that GCT remains somewhat reasonably valued at current levels despite the outsized rally from the $33s.

This is significantly aided by the richer free cash flow generation of $182.79M in FY2025 (+28.2% YoY) and the consequently healthier balance sheet at a net cash position of $379.78M (+46.2% YoY) with zero debts (aside from lease liabilities).

This reason is also why the management has been able to return great value to long-term shareholders through the -9.3% of their float retired over the LTM, with it also contributing to the drastically richer EPS of $1.04 in FY2025 (+36.8% YoY).

When comparing GCT's extremely healthy balance sheet at a net debt-to-EBITDA ratio of -2.33x in FY2025 (given the growing cash and the zero debt) against AMZN at -0.39x, MELI at 1.16x, SE at -2.02x, and BABA at -4.02x, it is apparent that GCT remains well positioned to strategically invest in their capabilities while driving profitable growth prospects moving forward.

GCT Is Upgraded To A Buy Upon A Slight Correction

For now, GCT has been well supported along its uptrend support line since the April 2025 bottom, with the stock notably breaking out of the prior January 2026 highs of $44s while retesting the 2024 top of $46s by the time of writing.

Given the outsized rally post-FQ4'25 earnings call, it is unsurprising that GCT has already entered overbought territories by the time of writing, as similarly observed in the elevated RSIs.

If anything, readers may want to note that the stock typically experiences short-term volatility post-earnings calls, as observed in the oval annotations above, potentially attributed to its small-cap status at below-market capitalization of $2B, worsened by the small float at 38.23M and the short interest ratio of 6.55%.

For now, based on the current stock price of $46.98 and the FY2025 EPS performance of $3.59 (+8.3% YoY), GCT is trading at an estimated FY2025 P/E GAAP valuation of 13.08x, cheap compared to the sector median of 17.70x and the peer group mean of ~24x.

Based on the consensus FY2027 EPS estimates of $4.26, there remains a decent upside potential:

  • of +18.5% to my bear-case long-term price target of $55.70, based on my estimated P/E GAAP valuations of 13.08x, or
  • of +54.1% to my base-case long-term price target of $72.40, assuming an upward re-rating in its valuations nearer to the sector median of ~17x, or
  • of +117.5% to my bull-case long-term price target of $102.20, assuming an upward re-rating in its valuations nearer to the peer group mean of ~24x.

Does this mean that I am admitting the blunder that is my last Hold rating, albeit validating my two prior Buy ratings?

Yes indeed, with GCT upgraded to a Buy, albeit with the caveat that interested investors observe a slight correction to the December 2025/Q1'26 support levels of $38s or the 50-day moving averages of $39s for an improved margin of safety.

Given the potential -16% downside from current levels, it may be more prudent to wait for part of the exuberance to be moderated in the meantime.

data.title: Energy Fuels: Big Gains But Stretched Valuations
data.description:
When I last checked on uranium and rare earths' miner Energy Fuels Inc. (UUUU) in April last year, I put a Hold rating on the stock based on weak financial forecasts coupled with stretched market valuations. I couldn't have been more wrong. The stock is up by almost 400% since.

Just in 2026 alone, the stock is up by over 50%. Let me put this in perspective. While it has been a good time for both uranium and rare earths as the US aims to secure supplies, neither the Global X Uranium ETF (URA) nor the VanEck Rare Earths and Strategic Minerals ETF (REMX) come close to matching this rise (see chart below). But with the release of the company's full-year 2025 results today, the question is whether it can sustain the price rise.

Uranium production and sales impress...

The results are a mixed bag, but they don't take away from the fact that the company has made some big strides. To start with, uranium production surprised on the upside, as mined amounts came in 20% higher than the top end of the guidance range (see table below) and 49% higher than the midpoint of the guidance range.

Similarly, processed uranium production was also a shade higher than the top-end of the guidance, and 20% higher than the midpoint. Sales volumes were significantly higher by 85% compared to the target of 350k.

As a result, uranium revenues rose by 27.3%. This is a complete reversal from my expectations last year, which had forecast a 56% drop in the number. Instead, the actuals came in 189% higher. This was for two reasons:

  • At the time of these estimates, the midpoint sales guidance itself was lower at 250,000 pounds, which was subsequently revised upwards by 40%. And as earlier mentioned, the actual sales significantly exceeded even the upwardly revised guidance.
  • Next, the realized uranium price assumption was USD 66.7 per pound, based on the price at that time. The actual figure was 11.2% higher at USD 74.2 per pound.

...but heavy mineral sands affect revenues

Even then, though, total revenues contracted by 15.6% due to a pullback in revenues for heavy mineral sands, which represent the rare earths segment for Energy Fuels. Heavy mineral sands' revenue, dropped by 60% after the closure of the Kwale mine in Kenya in 2024.

The pullback in total revenue wasn't surprising, though, as my estimates had forecast a drop in uranium revenues. If anything, the extent of the drop was a relief. Even with an assumption of unchanged heavy mineral sands' revenues, a 27.6% drop in revenue was projected.

With revenue weakness anticipated, I also pencilled in a loss in 2025, which also came to pass. In fact, the loss ballooned by 1.8x due to costs associated with the company's acquisition of the Australian rare earths producer Base Resources in late 2024, as well as expenses related to the company's expansion.

Exceptional revenue growth to be seen in 2026

Revenues in 2026, however, can look significantly better, based on the company's production and sales guidance as well as its recent acquisition of another rare earths producer, Australian Strategic Materials (OTCPK:ASMMF). The details are below:

  • Robust production outlook for uranium: The production outlook for 2026 is robust, with a 31% increase in mined uranium and a much bigger 97% increase in processed uranium expected at the midpoint of the guidance ranges as provided (see table below). But the biggest increase is expected in sales, of 169%. Even if realised uranium price were to remain unchanged from 2025 and heavy mineral sands' revenues were to be nil, Energy Fuels would still see a near doubling in revenues from 2025.

  • Expanding rare earths production potential: Next, there's the company's recent decision to acquire the rare earths producer Australian Strategic Materials through a share swap agreement plus a special dividend payout. This could add marginally to revenues as well, as Australian Strategic Materials has seen average annual revenues of USD 2.8 million over the past five years.

However, Energy Fuels' losses could increase even further in 2026, considering that Australian Strategic Materials' net losses have averaged USD 13.6 million annually over the past five years. For context, this amounts to ~16% of Energy Fuels' loss in 2025.

Stronger longer-term prospects...

Looking beyond this year, there are solid developments underway that can continue to support Energy Fuels' growth over the longer term, both from the perspective of rare earths and uranium.

Russia and China hold dominant global positions in the supply of processed uranium and rare earths, respectively. With the US at loggerheads with both, ensuring security for these critical minerals has been underlined in recent times. Companies like Energy Fuels are well suited to make gains from this strategic development.

It was already the biggest uranium producer in the US, and after its acquisition of Australian Strategic Materials, it has also become the biggest rare earths producer outside of China. While its rare earths' production is nil right now, the company aims to start producing dysprosium and terbium, both of which are restricted by China, in early 2027. Further, construction on the Vara Mada project in Madagascar, with promising financials and a mine life of 38 years, is due to start in 2026.

In the meantime, the company's uranium production can continue to benefit from the solid prospects as nuclear energy receives significant policy support and demand from big tech to power up their data centres.

...but price run-up indicates stretched valuations

In financial terms, however, the extreme price run-up means that the stock is seeing stretched valuations. For 2026, my estimates indicate that the company can see a revenue of USD 130 million, which results in a forward P/S of 41.7x. This is much lower than the stock's five-year average forward ratio of 65.9x.

However, the extreme price increase over the past year means that it's no longer a reliable indicator of what's next for the price. With uranium production and sales expected to be Energy Fuels' dominant focus in 2026, I compared how the stock stands against Cameco Corporation (CCJ) instead. The big Canadian miner's forward P/S for this year is at a far smaller 20.2x.

With the company expected to turn profitable next year (see graphic below), over the longer term, the forward P/E is the relevant market multiple to consider. For 2029, analysts estimates on Seeking Alpha indicate a forward ratio of 51.9x. This, too, remains at least slightly high. For CCJ, the corresponding figure is at ~47x. I also compared it with the rare earths' producer MP Materials (MP), which is at 27.2x.

What's next?

Whichever way the valuations are considered, they look high right now. Of course, the company has projects underway, like Vara Mada, with promising estimates. But it will take a while to operationalise and the actuals could turn out different than current estimates.

That said, there's a lot going for Energy Fuels right now. In terms of its critical minerals focus and its leading position as a US-based producer, it's in just the right position to reap the benefits of supportive policies. The company's latest production and sales numbers for uranium are only encouraging, and its outlook for 2026 is even more so.

The best course of action right now, would be to buy on any significant dips that reflect reduced market multiples. Otherwise, it's best to wait for more stability in financials before taking a call, especially for long-term investors. I'm retaining a Hold rating.

data.title: 2 BDCs To Buy For Stress-Free Retirement Cash Flow
data.description:
The private credit space (BIZD) has been completely obliviated by the bears and market participants, who believe that the current headlines around SaaS and liquidity squeeze a) will translate into actual consequences and b) these consequences will come very close or even exceed the credit risks, which are already baked into the cake.

If we take a step back and look at what has happened.

The inflection point of business development company, or BDC, outperformance dates back to the tariff tantrum, back in April, 2025. While the entire market sold off, the BDC sector got hammered extra hard and remained subdued for a longer time than the S&P 500 (SPY).

Then once everyone realized that actually the tariffs won’t have as drastic consequences as initially thought and the BDCs continued to deliver solid credit quality statistics, it took less than 4 months for the recovery process to get abrupted again. This time it was the bankruptcy of First Brands and Tricolor and the corresponding “cockroach” phrase that threw the BDCs back to square one.

Some months later, realizing that the promised cockroaches were somehow not emerging, the market initiated BDC recovery process again, which lasted until late January, 2026, when the SaaS aspect started to gain traction as a reason for BDC repricing. And here the dynamics at one of Blue Owl Capital Corporation (OWL) private BDCs (OBDC II) came into play right around the same time, when SaaS selloff was at its peak moment. As a result of this combination, almost all BDCs plunged and entered into even steeper discount zones.

Currently, the market is assuming that about 23% of BDC NAVs (this includes the leverage effects) are effectively worthless.

The question becomes whether this time it is different. Could it be so that the BDC SaaS exposures (which are indeed material for many BDCs) fail and get converted to non-performing assets?

I doubt it because of the following (in no particular order):

  • In the Q4 earning call, the BDC management teams have all expressed no fears about SaaS investment blowout in their portfolios.
  • The non-accrual levels of the BDCs that have so far reported their Q4 reports have remained rock-solid and in most cases the underlying companies have reported growing EBITDA generation levels.
  • BDCs differ from broadly syndicated loan market as they typically implement strict underwriting standards, which come with conservative covenants and ample margin of safety (e.g., interest coverage levels at 2x+ and LTVs below 50%).
  • The SaaS-driven non-accrual risk sounds like a broken record. It is only logical that BDCs go through cycles as they are inherently cyclical investments. And usually right at the cyclical lows, it is when bargain opportunities emerge that can warrant greater upside than just the offered dividend. This is what happened in the GFC, COVID-19, in 2022 when the interest rates were surging etc.

Having said that, I fully appreciate the fact that for some investors venturing into BDCs at their cyclical lows when the risks are elevated and the future seems very uncertain might not be acceptable.

For example, it could be so that the level of stress that would come with making BDC bets right would not compensate for the extra return potential.

So, with this in mind, I would like to elaborate on two bulletproof BDCs, which could be bought right now, knowing that both portfolios and dividends are isolated from the SaaS-induced non-accruals.

2 durable NAV and safe dividend BDC picks

If I had to recommend two BDCs, which, in my view, offer the strongest level of protection from not only SaaS bankruptcies but also from a system-wide credit stress in the private credit space, I would go with Capital Southwest (CSWC) and Main Street Capital Corporation (MAIN).

It does not mean that these are my highest conviction buys from an attractive total return perspective, but certainly these would be picks that I could see in prudent retirement income investor's portfolio for whom a base dividend cut or a permanent value impairment is not an option.

Let me share four reasons, which should substantiate my stance.

First, it depends on a BDC, but many of the largest and well-known BDCs such as Sixth Street Specialty Lending (TSLX), Blackstone Secured Lending Fund (BXSL) and Blue Owl Capital Corporation (OBDC) (but I could go on and on) carry meaningful exposures to SaaS sector. Typically, the portfolio bias towards SaaS is somewhere between 15% to 25%.

However, for both CSWC and MAIN the exposure to SaaS is below 5%. In CSWC's case we cannot see it at a granular level, but given that it is not present in the Top 10 industry mix, which has 4% as the lowest mark, we can draw a conclusion that for CSWC the SaaS segment consumes less than 4% of the total book. For MAIN we can see this more clearly - i.e., SaaS accounts for ~2% of the LMM loan book and less than 8% of the private credit loan book (on a weighted average basis it translates to sub 4% exposure).

Already here we can basically neutralize the SaaS blowout risk.

Second, CSWC and MAIN invest with a strong margin of safety. The average portfolio company for these two BDCs has more robust leverage and interest coverage metrics than what we typically see for core middle market names.

For example, the weighted average leverage for CSWC portfolio company is only 3.6x, while the sector average falls closer to 4.5x. For MAIN's portfolio investments the leverage metric is even lower. And for example, the EBITDA to senior interest coverage is at 3.0x for MAIN's LMM investments, which means that the company would have to lose about two thirds of its EBITDA (business) to cause some real headache for the BDC.

Third, CSWC and MAIN are very well-positioned to expand their portfolios further, which should in turn result in incremental NII generation that could, in the worst case, be used to offset pressures from non-accruals.

There are two elements to take into account when thinking about growth capacities:

  1. Additional borrowings. CSWC has a debt to equity of 1.08x, which is meaningfully below the sector average of 1.20x and a clear indicative of available debt capacity for growth in a financially prudent manner. For MAIN the debt load is much lower - i.e., debt to equity of 0.74x, which ranks it as the third lowest debt BDC out there.
  2. Fresh and accretive equity. Since CSWC and MAIN are internally managed BDCs and carry high-quality portfolios they trade at relatively healthy valuations, where the P/NAVs are above 1.0x. The presence of above NAV multiples enables accretive equity issuances that can provide capital for portfolio growth. Majority of BDCs do not have this (access to equity capital) available.

Fourth, and this is also quite unique and important in the context of NAV stability and dividend durability, both BDCs could be deemed as equity-biased. Namely, the portfolios are saturated with high-quality equity investments, which can unlock further upside in the form of realized gains.

CSWC has 9.1% of its portfolio tied to high-quality equity investments. For MAIN the figure is even higher as the cumulative pre-tax net unrealized appreciation of its equity investments accounts for 11.7% of the total market cap.

Again, the benefit of the equity tilt is that as these investments get monetized (happens periodically) they result in notable equity-like gains, which can balance out the headwinds from non-accruals or contribute to further NAV and dividend growth.

Final words

What we are currently seeing is yet another reminder that BDCs are cyclical instruments. When the sentiment shifts, they quickly drop into a deeply discounted zone, which is actually the right time to buy.

However, going out in the market and scooping up discounted names, while the storm is still in the process is difficult. The risk of stepping into value traps is for sure higher than in normal times. Also, opening BDC positions right now might not necessarily be a stress-free exercise, which is also a critical aspect for many investors that I fully respect.

So here I see a merit of buying CSWC and MAIN names, which still produce tangible dividends (11.5% by CSWC and 7.3% by MAIN) and are insulated from SaaS credit risks.

In this context, I would like to also insert the historical total return performance chart:

It really goes well in line with my thesis that MAIN and CSWC are indeed durable investment plays that have what it takes to withstand different cycles without value impairment.

data.title: SCZ ETF: There's Other, Better, Cheaper Options
data.description:
SCZ Overview

The iShares MSCI EAFE Small-Cap ETF (SCZ) is a passively managed exchange-traded fund (also known as an ETF) that invests in small-capitalization equities from developed markets outside the United States and Canada. BlackRock launched the fund in December 2007, and it has grown to $14 billion+ in net assets — making it a dominant vehicle in the foreign small/mid-cap blend category by AUM. The fund’s benchmark is the MSCI EAFE Small Cap Index, and as a full-replication passive fund, BlackRock simply holds a proportionate share of the index constituents, rebalancing periodically in line with index changes.

After years of sluggish results, SCZ, and international equity's moment arrived. The fund posted a 32.10% NAV return in calendar year 2025, its strongest showing in recent memory, and is up approximately 9.06% year-to-date through February 23, 2026. International developed market equities have been the standout trade of the young year as investors rotate away from richly valued U.S. mega-cap growth names and toward markets with more attractive valuations and improving macro backdrops. On that front, I have no complaints about what SCZ is doing or where it invests. The issue is purely about cost — and in the passive ETF space, cost is ultimately the game.

SCZ’s benchmark, the MSCI EAFE Small Cap Index, is a credible and well-constructed benchmark covering the small-cap segment of developed markets in Europe, Australasia, and the Far East. Passive investing here means the fund managers are not making active bets — they are tracking the index. But when a passive fund charges 0.40% to do something its competitors do just as well for 0.07% or 0.11%, you have to ask what you are actually paying for. I'll keep this fund as a hold - worth keeping an eye on but not the best option for international small-cap equity.

Fund Breakdown

SCZ was launched on December 10, 2007, by BlackRock’s iShares platform. The fund currently holds 2,010 securities as of December 31, 2025, making it one of the broadest portfolios in the category by holding count. This is a genuine differentiator — at the other end of the spectrum, actively managed foreign small-cap funds often hold 40 to 80 names, and even many passive peers hold fewer constituents. With the top 10 positions accounting for just 2.92% of total assets, no single company or sector event is going to materially impair the NAV. Morningstar recognized this quality, awarding the fund a Bronze medal rating as of April 2025. That said, the fund has struggled versus passive, cheaper indexes, and even after a strong 2025, the fund lagged the passive index by a few percent.

From a liquidity standpoint, SCZ is well-suited to institutional and retail investors alike, averaging approximately 1.27 million shares traded per day on NASDAQ. The fund’s scale and liquidity at $14 billion in net assets also provides tight bid-ask spreads relative to smaller ETFs in the space. I’ll acknowledge these are real attributes — and they do narrow the gap versus some cheaper but thinner alternatives. But for the vast majority of individual investors, funds like Vanguard FTSE All-World ex-US Small-Cap Index ETF (VSS) and Schwab International Small-Cap Equity ETF (SCHC) are both sufficiently liquid that SCZ’s liquidity premium does not justify the fee premium.

The fund employs a 0.40% expense ratio. For context, this is the same fee charged by many actively managed ETFs in the space, which at least have the justification of paying for a portfolio manager’s judgement. SCZ is entirely passive. When I compare it to VSS at 0.07% or SCHC at 0.11%, the math is straightforward: SCZ costs an investor roughly 29 to 33 basis points per year more, every year, for a nearly identical outcome. On a $100,000 investment compounded over 10 years, that fee gap represents roughly $3,000 to $3,500 in foregone wealth — money that stays with BlackRock rather than with you.

2026 Outlook

The macro setup for international developed small-cap in 2026 is more constructive than it has been in years, and I want to be clear that I am bullish on the asset class — just not on SCZ specifically as the vehicle. The valuation gap between U.S. and international equities has widened to historically extreme levels over the past decade, and that gap has begun to close. A modestly weaker U.S. dollar, improving European fiscal outlooks, Japanese corporate governance reform, and better-than-expected domestic demand across the UK and Australia all support the EAFE small-cap recovery narrative.

Small-cap equities in developed international markets carry a higher domestic revenue exposure than their large-cap peers, which provides meaningful insulation from cross-border tariff disruption. This is an important nuance in the current environment, where Trump tariff unpredictability has created noise around global trade flows. If you want international equity exposure that is less sensitive to U.S.-China trade tensions and more levered to local economic recovery stories, the EAFE small-cap universe is a logical place to be.

That said, the January 2026 results were a reminder that SCZ is not always the sharpest tool even within its own category. The fund returned 5.4% in January, trailing the Foreign Small/Mid Blend category average of 6.2% for the month. Whether that is noise or a sign that VSS and SCHC’s slightly different index construction is producing better results remains to be seen, but it reinforces my view that SCZ is not even necessarily the best passive option in the space, let alone the best overall option.

Fund Portfolio & Risk Profile

Reviewing SCZ’s portfolio as of December 31, 2025, the sector and geographic breakdown reflect what you would expect from a broad index of developed international small caps. Industrials lead at 22.76% of the fund, followed by Financials (12.72%), Consumer Discretionary (12.27%), Real Estate (11.12%), and Materials (10.88%). Information Technology accounts for just 9.13%, which is a far cry from its dominance in U.S. benchmarks. Investors coming from an S&P 500 or Nasdaq-heavy portfolio will find SCZ’s sector mix genuinely different — and that diversification benefit is real.

Geographically, Japan is the dominant weight at 35.09% of the fund, followed by the United Kingdom (12.60%), Australia (10.92%), Sweden (5.30%), and Israel (4.59%). The Japan concentration is notable and means that SCZ investors are implicitly making a significant bet on the Japanese macro story, including the Bank of Japan’s gradual monetary normalization and whether the corporate governance reform wave translates into sustained earnings improvement. This is a reasonable bet, but it is a concentrated one for a fund that markets itself on broad diversification.

From a risk perspective, the fund has an beta of 1.09. The beta above 1 reflects the higher volatility though it is a portfolio diversification characteristic, not necessarily a sign that the fund is higher-risk in isolation. Additionally, the fund's 0.68 Sharpe ratio is underwhelming, as risk adjusted returns for other similar funds have been approaching 1, which is more palatable for investors.

Key Risks

The most significant fund-level risk is one I’ve already flagged: the fee. In a passive indexing context, the expense ratio is one of the only variables an investor can actually control, and paying 0.40% when comparable alternatives exist at 0.07% is a structural drag on compounded returns that never goes away. Every year you hold SCZ over VSS, you are handing back roughly 33 basis points to BlackRock for no incremental benefit.

Beyond fees, currency is the primary market-level risk. SCZ holds stocks denominated in yen, pounds, euros, Australian dollars, and Swedish krona, and USD-based investors bear this exposure in full without any hedging. A meaningful U.S. dollar strengthening — whether from tariff escalation, a hawkish Federal Reserve pivot, or a global flight to safety — would compress the fund’s USD-denominated returns even if underlying foreign stock prices were flat. This is a known and accepted feature of unhedged international ETFs, but it is a real source of short-term volatility.

Japan’s 35% weighting is also a concentration risk that deserves mention. Any disorderly yen appreciation, JGB market volatility, or disappointment in Japan’s corporate governance reform trajectory could have an outsized impact on SCZ relative to peers with a different geographic mix. And on the macro side, tariff uncertainty, European fiscal headwinds, and the pace of global rate normalization all remain live risks for an asset class that is only just recovering its footing after years of underperformance.

Bottom Line

The bottom line is that I like the asset class, but not the wrapper of SCZ. International developed small-cap equity is one of the better places to be in 2026, and SCZ’s strong 2025 performance and year-to-date gains reflect genuine fundamental improvement in the asset class rather than just momentum. The portfolio is well-diversified across 2,010 holdings, the fund is liquid, and the Morningstar Bronze rating provides some external validation of the fund’s quality.

But paying 0.40% for a passive index fund in 2026 is simply unnecessary. VSS at 0.07% and SCHC at 0.11% do the same job for a fraction of the cost, and that difference compounds into real money over a multi-year holding period. If you want international small-cap exposure — and there are good reasons to want it right now — there are more efficient vehicles to get it. For existing SCZ holders with significant embedded capital gains, holding makes sense and I am not suggesting you trigger a tax event to save 33 basis points annually. But for new money entering this asset class, I would not be starting with SCZ. I rate it a Hold.

data.title: DiamondRock Hospitality Company: Set To Shine
data.description:
Introduction

DiamondRock Hospitality (DRH) presents a compelling option to potential investors. The company boasts a strong balance sheet with significant flexibility and ever-growing dividends.

I have written about several hospitality REITs previously, most recently on Sunstone Hotel Investors (SHO). However, this will be my first time writing about DiamondRock Hospitality Company. With the company having realized its Q4 2025 earnings earlier this week, I figure now would be a good time to evaluate the company.

Portfolio

As of Q4 2025, DiamondRock Hospitality Company’s portfolio comprises 36 hotels with a total of 9,595 rooms. The hotels are diversified across luxury resorts, lifestyle resorts, urban lifestyle hotels, and urban gateway hotels, with their demand mix being fairly split among leisure transient (39%), business transient (27%), and group (35%).

The portfolio is also well-diversified geographically, with Boston, Chicago, and New York City representing the largest market concentration at 13.3%, 12.5%, and 8.2% of EBITDA respectively. Apart from these 3 markets, no other market accounts for more than 7% of total EBITDA, which reduces concentration risk.

A distinct difference between DiamondRock Hospitality Company and its peers in the hospitality industry is its predominantly third-party managed portfolio model. 23 of the company’s hotels, representing 56% of the total portfolio revenue, are managed by independent operators. This structure provides the company with greater control over expenses, capital expenditures, and cash flow. With contracts being short-term and terminable at will, there is significant flexibility to quickly test and implement profit-enhancing technologies, and decisions can be made specifically for each hotel's unique needs. In fact, the company’s third-party managed properties have consistently outperformed its brand-managed properties.

Balance Sheet

In July 2025, the company successfully refinanced its senior unsecured credit facility, increasing it from $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion. The company used this additional amount to repay the existing mortgage loans secured by 2 of its properties. Subsequent to the repayment, and as of Q4 2025, the company’s total debt stands at $1.1 billion with a weighted average interest rate of 4.98%. This debt is comprised entirely of unsecured term loans, with the earliest maturity coming in January 2028, almost 2 years later. All debt is prepayable at any time without penalty, and the floating rate nature of the debt means the company stands to benefit from a declining rate environment.

As of Q4 2025, the company has liquidity of approximately $468 million, comprising $68.1 million in cash and cash equivalents and $400 million from its undrawn revolving credit facility. This, coupled with the relatively long duration till its next maturity, means the company has substantial available capital to deploy strategically, or even for emergencies. Its portfolio is also fully unencumbered by secured debt, which does provide an additional option for the company to raise funds if necessary. The company has a net debt + preferred to EBITDA of approximately 3.5x, marking it on the lower end compared to its peers in the same space.

One example of the flexibility the company has due to its strong balance sheet came in December 2025, when the company redeemed all 4.76 million shares of its 8.250% Series A Preferred Stock for approximately $121.5 million cash on hand. This eliminates approximately $9.8 million in annual preferred dividends, and positively impacts the company’s Funds From Operations (FFO) by approximately $0.03/share. In all, this move has improved the company’s cash flow.

Dividends

For 2025, DiamondRock Hospitality Company declared a total dividend of $0.36/share, comprising quarterly dividends of $0.08/share and a stub dividend of $0.04/share. The total dividend of $0.36/share represents a 12.5% increase over 2024. The company also stated that it expects to increase its quarterly dividend to $0.09/share for 2026, and possibly pay a stub dividend in Q4 2026 as well. Even excluding the stub dividend, this represents yet another 12.5% increase in the regular dividend, and gives the company a forward dividend yield of 3.6% at minimum (based on the current share price of $10/share).

A quick glance at the company’s Adjusted Funds From Operations (AFFO) shows that this current dividend is sustainable. AFFO for the year came in at $1.08/share, triple the total dividend of $0.36/share paid. Moreover, management has also indicated that the company will continue growing its dividends over the next few years.

Valuation

DiamondRock Hospitality Company is currently trading at approximately $10/share, significantly higher than its 52-week low of approximately $6.19/share, reflecting the market’s confidence in the company.

A look at the price targets from other analysts indicates that the company is currently fairly valued, with the average price target at $10.23/share, only slightly higher than the present value. Notably, the most recent ratings, which have come from Deutsche Bank and Truist Securities, have been positive.

Deutsche Bank upgraded the company to a “Buy” and raised its price target from $10/share to $12/share, citing “relative valuation” and “revamped focus on net free cash flow” as a positive for the company, while Truist Securities also upgraded the company to a “Buy” and raised its price target to $11, citing its valuation as a key factor.

All things considered, it seems like the company is either fairly valued or slightly undervalued at present, but market sentiment surrounding the company is positive.

Q4 2025 Earnings and Catalysts
