DiamondRock Hospitality Company reported good Q4 2025 results, which exceeded guidance, even after having revised it upwards following a good Q3 2025. Notably, the company’s full-year AFFO/share of $1.08/share was 3.8% higher compared to the previous year.

Looking at the 2026 guidance, there are certainly reasons to be optimistic. AFFO/share is expected to come in at between $1.09/share and $1.16/share. At the midpoint of around $1.12/share, this represents another 3.7% increase compared to 2025. This also supports management’s assertion that they will continue to increase dividends in the coming years.

In terms of catalysts, the most obvious one would be the 2026 FIFA World Cup, which will be held across the United States, Canada, and Mexico in June and July 2026 and is expected to be a significant boost to the company. The company has meaningful EBITDA exposure to several host and surrounding markets, such as Boston, Florida, and New York City. Hotel bookings in the host cities have surged, which bodes well for the company’s 2026 performance.

Apart from the World Cup, one of the most compelling advantages the company has is that there is negligible new supply affecting its portfolio. 29 of its 36 hotels have no competitive submarket supply under construction, with supply constraints expected to persist for several years.

Potential Risks

As always, there are potential risks to consider. Firstly, macroeconomic sensitivity. As a hospitality REIT, the company’s performance is tied to economic conditions. There have been declines in leisure transient travel and international travel to the country, in part due to the current political and economic environment, including tariff-related uncertainty. Any recession or significant decline in consumer confidence would inevitably have a negative impact on the company’s performance.

Another risk comes in the form of interest rate risk. With the bulk of the company’s debt being floating rate (70%, net of swaps), the company faces a substantial increase in interest expense should there be a rise in rates. For example, a 100 basis point increase would add approximately $7.7 million in annual interest expense, almost wiping out the savings from eliminating its preferred stock dividend.

One last risk to consider would be that of valuation. As indicated above, the company is currently either fairly valued or slightly undervalued, with consensus price targets coming in around the company’s current share price. Moreover, the stock’s recovery from its low of $6.19/share means most of the near-term upside has been captured, and there is less margin for error.

Conclusion

DiamondRock Hospitality Company has a strengthened and fully unencumbered balance sheet, as well as a supply-insulated portfolio of hotels. Management has consistently sought (and succeeded) to increase free cash flow per share, and they have returned capital to shareholders in the form of increased dividends. While the stock is likely fairly valued at present, it represents a quality holding, and I rate it a “Buy.”

data.title: February Non-Farm Payrolls Report Preview: Labor Market Stability Is Now Crucial
data.description:
Consensus expectations

The US Bureau of Labor Statistics BLS is set to release February labor market report on Friday, March 6th. Consensus expectations are that:

  • Non-farm payrolls increased by 60K, which would be well below 130K jobs created in January, and
  • the unemployment rate remained at 4.3%, unchanged from January.

Thus, the expectations are that job creation remained sluggish in February, while labor market still remained tight with the unemployment rate near the full employment level.

Macro context - unfolding credit crisis

On macro level, it is imperative that labor market stays solid, or more specifically that the unemployment rate stays relatively stable, below the 4.5% level.

Specifically, it looks like there is an early-phase financial crisis unfolding, triggered by the private credit bubble burst. Based on the recent information, around 40% of private credit loans are extended to software companies, which are currently being disrupted by advanced AI tools. Thus, according to UBS, the default rate could be as high as 15% on these loans. Most importantly, large banks are heavily exposed because they lend to these private credit funds.

However, the bust in private credit is not sufficiently large to cause a systemic credit shock and the crisis like 2008 GFC - unless the labor market weakens. In this situation, a spike in the unemployment rate could burst the housing market bubble, the CRE bubble, and increase consumer loan defaults, which would likely trigger a financial crisis comparable to 2008.

Thus, a stable labor market is now crucial in preventing contagion from the private credit crisis to the rest of the economy. The key issue here is whether AI adoption will cause massive layoffs - and the February labor market report could give us some clues.

Leading indicators for February

The leading indicators for February point to a sluggish job creation, but still a tight labor market, consistent with consensus expectations. Thus, I don't expect any major surprises.

The S&P Global US Flash PMI for February points to some weaknesses, which could be weather related. For service jobs, the report states:

Sluggish sales growth and concerns over rising costs led to a further month of very modest employment growth, albeit with some companies also reporting difficulties finding staff. Payrolls rose only marginally for a third successive month and at the weakest rate since last April. Hiring slowed to marginal rates in both manufacturing and services.

Specifically, for manufacturing jobs, the report states:

Employment came close to stalling amid the weaker demand environment, registering the smallest increase since last July.

The ADP Weekly jobs report actually points to a modest strengthening during the first week of February, with a slight increase in new jobs created, consisted with around 50-60K jobs created on a monthly basis.

The weekly Initial Claims have been at a historically very low levels during February, which suggests a low firing rate, and a tight labor market.

The Chicago Fed predicts that the unemployment rate remained unchanged in February at 4.28%.

Thus, the leading indicators for February all still point to a low fire/low hire labor market, which is positive in the current macro environment.

Recent labor market trends

When looking at the recent trends, it actually looks like the job creation is improving and broadening.

The ISM manufacturing employment index had a spike in January, and while still below 50, it points to an improved hiring in the manufacturing sector. Note, President Trump wants to boost manufacturing sector, and this could be early signal of the revival of US manufacturing leading to the mid-terms.

The ISM services employment index spiked in December, and then contracted in January, but still slightly above 50, which points to a positive but sluggish service sector job creation.

The most important improvement in the labor market is signaled by the 3-month change in non-farm payrolls. Over the last 12 months, virtually all jobs have been created in Private Education and Health Services, with some in Leisure & Hospitality. However, over the last 3 months there have been 65K jobs created in construction, and 105K jobs created in business and professional services.

Note, President Trump referenced 70K construction jobs created in his State of the Union address. I fact-checked it, and it's (nearly) true.

The first phase of Trump's plan is construction of factories, which will be evident in new construction jobs created - while the second phase is creation of manufacturing jobs (once the factories are constructed).

What's also interesting is the creation of 105K jobs in business and professional and business services, where 30K new jobs have been created in Temporary Help services, as the chart below shows. This is positive since Temp jobs are considered as a leading indicator - generally contracting before a recession. Note, the downtrend in Temp jobs ended in October, with a subsequent rebound.

At the same time, over the last 12 months there have been nearly 50K jobs lost in Computer System Design industry, which is part of Professional and Business services sector, and this likely represents layoffs due to AI adoption.

Overall,

Overall, the US labor market is still sluggish, but the recent increase in Construction jobs, and Temp jobs point to a strengthening labor market leading to the mid-term elections, which is exactly what President Trump wants.

The key things to consider:

  • whether the SCOTUS decision on tariffs delays FDI, and negatively affects labor market - this will be evident in construction jobs.
  • whether the AI adoption leads to massive layoffs - this will be evident in a cross-section of white-collar jobs, and most specifically in Computer System Design jobs, with macro implications as previously discussed.

Implications

The financial markets are in a precarious state.

  • First, there is the AI bubble where the ROI on AI capex is questioned.
  • Second, there is the AI disruption, where AI adoption is making some industries obsolete, like the software industry, with the risk of massive layoffs.
  • Third, there is a private credit crisis, where major banks are exposed.
  • Fourth, there is an escalating geopolitical situation with a possible US-Iran war, with implications on price of oil (USO), and thus inflation.

The S&P500 (SP500) is trading at Shiller PE above 40 - and that's a bubble comparable to the 2000 dot.com bubble.

As long as the labor market remains stable, the bubble can stay inflated, because investors will rotate from one sector to another keeping the (SPX) index level price in the range - that's the story on 2026 YTD.

Based on the available data, the February labor market report is unlikely to trigger the bubble burst.
